In reading many of the insightful comments/explanations below that provide very thoughtful inside/outside probabilities, many were authored prior to a significant global COVID outbreak. A base rate informed by pre-COVID attack trends between the US & Iran, IMO, must be modified to reflect the COVID context. In which direction? Let's look at the domestic contexts for action (inside view):
Iran: significant COVID infection scandal; poor public opinion of govt; increasingly diminished resources thanks to sanctions, COVID, and oil market crash; continued anti-American rhetoric and warnings; public still smarting over Soleimani death
US: bellicose POTUS that responded violently to Iranian provocations/attacks previously; almost 1 million COVID cases; upcoming presidential election; devastated economy; tweets for US Navy to destroy Iranian ships that harass them.
These factors could tip the balance in either way (attack to distract, rally around the flag or don't attack bc it exacerbates uncertainty too much). I lean toward the latter--the risk of exacerbating uncertainty will be too high for both governments during COVID, but I think the inside view is mostly indeterminate.
The outside view should consider the average rate of attack annually (monthly?) between the US and Iran, the targets of those attacks (are national forces postured at the targets), the accuracy of those attacks (probability of killing a national force) as a rough start point. Based on the calculations of these probabilities by smart people below, I'd say the general base rate is very low, 10-20%, but is elevated in 2020 given the number of attacks that have taken place within the last six months and the momentum this has generated, so I bump to the 20-30% probability. Update: I'm dropping my probability slightly based on the current international climate (COVID preoccupation) and the likelihood that Iran will avoid provoking the hawk Trump when they could just wait a few short months and test the resolve of the new US President. At the same time, the US is absorbed with domestic issues, and so it's still reasonable that Iran could allow something to happen or it happen inadvertently. Update 12/3/20: I'm dropping my forecast probability slightly to reflect the closing window of time during which a lethal event would have to occur, but not reducing as much as I would if not for the press on: Trump administration taking potential action against Iran in final days in office, the assassination of Iranian nuclear scientist allegedly by US ally Israel, and the reported potential for renegotiation of the JCPOA under the Biden administration. New forecast: 12%.

- Supporting INFO: Tensions due to POTUS-Iran communication. U.S. presence in countries like Saudi Arabia. "Iran surrounded by U.S. military bases & facilities" (ABC News). CNBC, NY Times & more; "Trump tells U.S. boats to destroy Iranian boats if harassed" (but it's a political statement that soldiers-on-the-ground often don't commit to as nonchalant, filtering threats to ensure just actions). - Contradictory INFO: No physical embassy (reduces chance of in-Iran collision). "Biden promises to rejoin Iran nuclear deal if Iran abide by the deal" (NBC News). A lethal confrontation could result in further sanctions, separation with supportive states, pull-out of foreign investors/stakeholders & maybe even a war with U.S. & perhaps its allies...this would only exacerbate the economic crisis and potential lead to an uprising. Iran claims the U.S. accusation of dangerous boating activities by Iran are "dramatized" by U.S. (suggesting interest by Iran to avoid further rise in tensions). Pentagon won't allow POTUS words to trigger an illegal act of war & soldiers will "preserve, protect & defend the Constitution", and are unlikely to start a war with Iran via confrontation unless justified, e.g. self-defense. "Tehran is seeking to exact a cost for U.S. sanctions that have battered its economy, but it wants to avoid all-out war." (Washington Post) Likelihood of confrontation in Iran: 6% | likelihood of lethal: 84%  ... Adjusted base = 3.4272%
Likelihood of confrontation at Sea: 22% | likelihood of lethal: 58%  ... Adjusted base = 8.6768%
Likelihood of confrontation in Airspace: 11%  | likelihood of lethal: 8%  ... Adjusted base = 0.5984%
Added adjusted bases: 12.70%
Probability of event occurring before 1 January 2021: 24% [reduced by transition of power in U.S.] RESULT: 3.05%
note; probability will gradually reduce as Biden assumes role as POTUS and tensions deflate.

At least 2-3 weeks will be spent fighting the election results. Mid-December is a holiday for most politicians and there is almost no way Trump starts a war at that point. This means, if the US is going to be the aggressor, it would have to be either late-November (Thanksgiving) or early December. There is no indication that this is on Trump's mind and this period will likely be filled more with lame-duck politics that benefit himself and his donors.
As for Iran, it is unlikely they want to stoke tensions at this point in time. While we are not on the best of terms, they don't want to start a war with the US any more than we want one with them. With the results of the election falling where they did, their best bet is to wait until the next administration comes in and try to come to an agreement with them instead of dealing with the current POTUS.

The US has been conducting FONOPS in the South China Sea for approximately 7 years without a fatal incident. I estimate that since the US and China are extraordinarily cautious, similar operations against Iran would probably result in one fatal incident in that time instead of zero (since the US especially may be less cautious toward Iran, which has less capability to strike back). Naively, one fatal incident in 84 months (7 years) projected over the remaining 1.75 months of 2020 results in about 2.08% odds. Notable assumptions:
- The US will not deliberately attack Iran, or vice versa. I believe this is easily justified for Iran, which would likely lose any military confrontation with the US. This is less justified for the US, but I believe that domestic politics (e.g. the election being over) means that the outgoing administration will be much less likely to start a confrontation without overt provocation from Iran.
- Conflicts will not occur in Iran or Iranian airspace. I believe that the US will refrain from operating inside Iran (excepting UAVs) barring a war, which was covered in the previous point.
For the the remainder of the year, Trump will be distracted by his legal battles/likely defeat.

Iran and the US have had bad relations for at least 40 years, but have come into open conflict only a few times. Tensions are higher than usual right now (although less than in January when this question was posed), but even so I think conflict in the next two months very unlikely. The US election increases my uncertainty a bit though.

I believe that USA has participated in 5 wars with American boots on the ground, since 1980, i.e. over the last 40 years. That’s Yugoslavia (airborne), Afghanistan, Iraq, Syria, Libya (US embassy attack), that’s 1 in 8 years, or 12.5%. I assign that as base probability that the US starts (or is dragged into) a new conflict.
Adjust for -5% for the fact that this is election year thus unlikely to start a war.
Adjust for -5% for the Covid/economic crisis situation that doesn’t encourage the huge expenditure of a conflict.
This leaves us with about 2.5% for intentional start idle a conflict.
Adjust for 10% upwards for the obvious American sabotage of a nuclear plant in Iran that might cause a retaliation.
Adjust for 5% upwards for accidental killing of an Iranian military staff which would still count Albe’s it not start a conflict.
I land at ~18%

sometimes it pays to go with your gut. Read my ACH analysis on the China-India question... then read where I went 100% against my analysis because of my Remote Viewing and gut...
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1047395 I applied the ACH method to this question last week. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analysis_of_competing_hypotheses "In researching the history of Chinese aggression, it is evident that while posturing and defense build-up has been common, there has been very little in the way of direct attacks or limited engagements in the past three decades. In the eyes of author Tom Doctoroff, China’s bark is worse than its bite and “given an adolescent economy and an immature body politic, China must focus on domestic imperatives” (Doctoroff, 2013). It is the job of the analyst to identify any judgmental biases “which are often systematic rather than random, in a certain direction” (Kam, 2004). “Prediction is extremely difficult and is likely often to be erroneous, particularly when it refers to international relations and military affairs” (Kam, 2004). Keeping these things in mind when applying logic to this situation and following Heuer’s method of giving the most weight to arguments that compete against the obvious conclusions derived from available evidence, it was easier to identify signal from noise. Relevant variables that could have been overlooked when giving the most weight to the obvious become more noticeable when giving the most weight to the argument. This was of great importance when evaluating this problem set. There is abundant evidence that an engagement of some sort would happen between the PRC and India. If Heuer’s method of giving the most weight to information that weakens a hypothesis had not been applied, an analysis concluding that a conflict was in the future for them may have been reached. However, these hypotheses were easily argued against when the most weight was given to the information that weakened the engagement hypotheses. In fact, these weakening arguments turned into lynchpins, and two out of three lynchpins supported a political outcome. The assessment reached in this analysis is that there will be a political solution to the PRC-India Crisis" Daveinsea INTEL401 May 30, 2020 Got a 97% on the paper and a 98% final grade in the class.

In reading many of the insightful comments/explanations below that provide very thoughtful inside/outside probabilities, many were authored prior to a significant global COVID outbreak. A base rate informed by pre-COVID attack trends between the US & Iran, IMO, must be modified to reflect the COVID context. In which direction? Let's look at the domestic contexts for action (inside view):
Iran: significant COVID infection scandal; poor public opinion of govt; increasingly diminished resources thanks to sanctions, COVID, and oil market crash; continued anti-American rhetoric and warnings; public still smarting over Soleimani death
US: bellicose POTUS that responded violently to Iranian provocations/attacks previously; almost 1 million COVID cases; upcoming presidential election; devastated economy; tweets for US Navy to destroy Iranian ships that harass them.
These factors could tip the balance in either way (attack to distract, rally around the flag or don't attack bc it exacerbates uncertainty too much). I lean toward the latter--the risk of exacerbating uncertainty will be too high for both governments during COVID, but I think the inside view is mostly indeterminate.
The outside view should consider the average rate of attack annually (monthly?) between the US and Iran, the targets of those attacks (are national forces postured at the targets), the accuracy of those attacks (probability of killing a national force) as a rough start point. Based on the calculations of these probabilities by smart people below, I'd say the general base rate is very low, 10-20%, but is elevated in 2020 given the number of attacks that have taken place within the last six months and the momentum this has generated, so I bump to the 20-30% probability.  How's that for a terrible, first-time forecast?!

It's been approximately 46 days since the U.S. strike that killed Soleimani.  The Islamic Republic News Agency barely mentions Soleimani - it lacks the front page fiery anti-U.S. rhetoric that would likely characterize an Iranian state-sanctioned response. Similarly, the Official Website of the President of the Islamic Republic of Iran does not mention Soleimani and the Official website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Islamic Republic of Iran makes only one front-page mention of Soleimani (dating from a 11 February 2020 article). Moreover, major U.S. news agencies have not reported any prominent statements emanating from Iran since late January. Further, despite the deployment of a 4,000-member Brigade from the 82nd Airborne, and some minor force protection enhancements in the region, the U.S. has not made public any major deployments of forces in the wake of the strike (e.g., carrier battle groups, Marine Expeditionary Forces, strike aircraft, Tomahawk-capable submarines, etc.). Likewise, open source intelligence has not reported any concerning Iranian troop or strategic asset movements (deployment of ballistic missile batteries to firing points, movement of troops to assembly areas, etc.). As such, it stands to reason that any retaliatory measures by Iran would have been initiated while the event was still fresh in the national memory. Either Iran is still in a "wait and see" period of assessing U.S. strategic moves while planning long-range escalatory measures, or Iran has accepted the strike as U.S. signaling that it had crossed a U.S. "red line," and intends to back down any provocative actions for the foreseeable future. This suggests to me that Iran will likely "lay low" for a while, until such time it decides to incrementally test the boundaries of U.S. strategic action, which in my opinion, will not be for several more months. Accordingly, at this point I am assessing the probability of a lethal confrontation involving at least one fatality between the military forces of either side in the airspace, seaspace, or landspace of Iran as low and very unlikely. Since there are still roughly 10-11 months remaining on the question, however, I'm leaving a margin open to the possibility.

I would envision lethal confrontation happening within three scenarios:
1) US initiated attack - Unlikely to occur given US House of Representatives votes to contain Trump's authorities and hinder availability of funding to support military action.  Additionally, US has taken other diplomatic and economic actions to address current tensions with Iran.
2) Iran initiated attack - I was fortunate to be able to discuss this situation with an Iraqi military officer, who did not think Iran would escalate military actions any further, though an initial response had to be taken to "save face." Given the history of military conflict between Iran and Iraq, I thought this to be excellent insight into the potential decision making calculus of Iranian officials. I am interested in reporting, however, of possible attacks occurring outside of the region, specifically within the African Continent (https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2020-01-30/us-general-iran-plotting-retaliatory-attacks-on-americans-in-Africa). Though a confrontation in this area would fall outside of the scope of this question, it does have the potential for follow up operations within Iranian controlled spaces (land, sea, air).
3) Unplanned encounter that escalates to lethal confrontation (i.e. accidents happen) - An unplanned encounter is the least predictable, and I believe, most likely scenario from which a lethal confrontation could occur. The US Navy has had a series of naval collisions (arguably in Southeast Asia) in the last five years. As such, it doesn't seem outside of the realm of possible that an unplanned encounter at sea could escalate causing the minimum of one fatality from either force.

I'm lowering my forecast by 10% after delving deeper into factors that formed my initial base rate and the current situation.  First, my original base rate was roughly 13% based on how few of incidents have occurred in the past 40+ years since the current Iranian government took power in 1979.  I'm not aware of any lethal conflicts between the US and Iran that specifically took place inside Iran or at sea since the mid-80s during the Iran-Iraq war.  Given the roughly 30-year gap in lethal conflicts inside the geographic parameters and the corresponding impact to the scope of the timeline of the question, I assess this makes the base rate lower.  Second, I increased my first forecast from the initial base rate based on the current situation.  However, updates to the current situation warrant lowering the forecast.  Iran accepting responsibility for the shoot down of the Ukrainian airliner decreases the likelihood of Iran conducting higher risk activities at sea or close to its borders in the near term (3-4 months).  Also, US public opinion according to Gallup is against military conflict with Iran.  As the next US election gets closer, I assess that US senior leaders will look to non-military responses (such as economic or diplomatic) before using any lethal military options against Iran.   When reflecting on what factors would cause me to think otherwise and increase the forecast, two potential scenarios come to mind.  First, if Iran increases military activity in other countries where it has proxies, the chances of a lethal conflict will increase.  Suleimani's replacement has not demonstrated whether he will maintain the same level of risk acceptance that Suleimani did.  Second, if economic sanctions decimate Iran's economy, Iran has shown in the past that it will lash out through military means, which will escalate the likelihood of lethal conflict.

Now that Iran has retaliated, and having learned a bit about Iran's foreign policy, it is time to update my previous forecast [1]. The inside view is that Iran's decisions will be aimed at continuing their long cold war with Saudi Arabia, while avoiding going as far as to trigger a direct retaliation from the US. This means that it is in the interest of their foreign policy to avoid an attack on the US at sea.  Yet I will not put the probability of this event as low as other forecasters: I will use the partial tit-for-tat model of the previous post, but with four attacks and a probability of 5% that they decide to hit an US vessel or an US plane flying over sea or Iran, followed by a further probability of 50% of victims in that kind of incident. The point is that geopolitical decisions are not necessarily rational. The same applies to the US. Actually the targeting of Soleimani makes much more sense than credited, because it will momentarily reduce the foreign operations of Iran in Iraq and the rest of the middle east. This is consistent with having a proxy war with Iran. But I consider the probability not to be as low as most forecasters are assuming right now. Just past year, after Iran shot an US drone, it was rumored that Trump cancelled an air strike on an Iranian target when it had been already launched. It is difficult to know whether this actually happened, but if it did it means that the chances are larger than acknowledged. Again, I will use the imperfect tit-for-tat model but with two attacks, 20-25% of targeting something within Iran (or an Iranian vessel) and a 50% of causalities if the attack happens. Finally I will also put a 2% probability that the US go nuts and decides to have a large conflict with Iran. Doing the calculations I obtain something in the 30-34% range, which I average to 32%. Notice that with the model I am using it is difficult to get very low probabilities, as the 10%'s many people are obtaining, while it also seems difficult to obtain the almost certainty of the initial forecasts for this question. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/940692

The day I posed my 72% forecast, Iran sent a dozen missiles towards US troops. My estimation was justified, but there were no reported casualties!
Furthermore, it seems intentional that there were no casualties, which surprised and intrigued me.  A war on Iran will hurt both countries. 
Iran, the second biggest exporter of oil in the OPEC nations, has an interest in keeping peace to protect their GDP. 
China may be able buy oil from Iran, but there is incentive for China to NOT enter a financial agreement that enables Iran to wage war. It could be seen as China waging war on the US by proxy - that view would certainly affect trade with the western world, I do not believe China will enter that deal.
Basically, Iran huge motivation to not enter into a war. The US are posturing to exit the region, it's been on Trump's agenda since he's election campaign started - they are unlikely to agree to extend the war (peace keeping)  in the middle east.  My estimates for war are LOW. However, the question is not will war start, it is: will there be a "lethal confrontation", "at least one fatality" my military forces - my estimation, given the tensions right now, is higher than for the chance of war.

In the detente following the Soleimani assassination, it became clear that neither side wants to escalate the conflict. Iran's funding is hurt by sanctions and although China has offered military (and financial assistance via oil purchases that do not require settlement in USD), I do not believe their economy can project power outside of Iran and the region effectively enough to make a significant statement to the US. Accordingly, they will suffer larger losses than the US. As for the US, there doesn't appear to be sufficient internal support for another conflict in the middle east and the region's allies are not interested in conflict at this time. Saudi is trying to expand its economy past petroleum centric activities and is even inviting tourism to the country (which will be hurt by conflict). Bahrain is teetering on bankruptcy. UAE has Expo 2020 on in October and so wants to ensure the event is successful and that will be measured by increased tourism for the event and afterwards. A task that is made difficult by regional conflict, particularly as Iran suggested that any escalation by the US will be countered by attacks on Dubai. Qatar seems to be surviving its regionally-imposed sanctions but with the world cup it is hosting coming up cannot risk regional conflict as it is unlikely (based on past conflicts) to be finished in time. It may also complicate completion timelines for a lot of the new infrastructure that needs to be built out in Qatar in advance of the event, particularly if shipping access via the Straight of Hormuz is compromised. In other words, no one regionally is incentivised to enter into a conflict that may very well turn into a prolonged regional conflict and that regional pressure on the US can lead to some interesting compromise (another topic altogether). I do give a minor probability to "lethal conflict" because there is always uncertainty, however improbable. Events which would increase the chance of conflict would be significant pivot by Gulf States to sell oil denominated in currencies (or gold) other than the US$. The need for foreigners to buy USTs is become a major "hidden" funding issue (unless you subscribe to MMT). Regardless, whilst the US government can self-fund by printing more money, effects on repo and other funding markets might not be able to cope and thus there may be economic incentives for the US to apply pressure to Gulf States to sell oil for dollars. However, there are many ways to get there without the need for conflict and so the probability here is small. Another reason for a small risk is that Iran is not an ideal country to attack. It is mountainous and largely uninhabitable and therefore after the air strikes would take out most of the country's strike capabilities, a ground force would be required to effect regime change and that would likely be a protracted battle against a very large army (much larger than Iraqi) with more sophisticated weaponry with established support from both Russia and China. I can probably write another page of reasons but this should be sufficient.

Assessing the situation in the USA:
1.	What is the US War Powers Resolution of 1973?  = Congress has the power to declare war while the president, as commander-in-chief, has the power to use the military to defend the US.  This is not new; the War Powers Act - which was enacted in 1973 about the veto of then-President Richard Nixon. Congress wanted to constrain Nixon's ability to further commit US forces to the unpopular Vietnam War.
2.	Why are war powers an issue now? = The air raid Trump ordered on Soleimani - a significant escalation - late last month in Iraq was undertaken without consultation or notice to Congress. It put US forces into imminent conflict, even a potential war with Iran that Congress has not authorised, Democrats argue. The Trump administration has [ratcheted up tensions](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/05/understanding-iran-deal-coming-180509072633096.html) with Iran since taking office in 2017. One of Trump's first decisions was to unilaterally withdraw from the 2015 United Nations-backed Iran nuclear deal, the JCPOA.
3.	In recent years, there has been a continuing debate in Congress on whether the 2001 and 2002 authorisations should be replaced with a new, more narrowly tailored congressional authority for US military action (In recent years, there has been a continuing debate in Congress on whether the 2001 and 2002 authorisations should be replaced with a new, more narrowly tailored congressional authority for US military action.)
Retaliatory Measures by the USA:
The purpose of stricter sanctions is not to change Iran’s behavior, but to crush the Iranian economy in an attempt to destabilize the regime. Iran is now in a US-induced depression, with GDP down 14% between 2017 and 2019 and inflation in 2019 at 36% (both according to [recent IMF estimates](https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2019/02/weodata/index.aspx)), and severe shortages of medicines and other vital goods.
Iran is unlikely to back down. 
1.	It has many options at its disposal, including a wide range of military, economic, and diplomatic targets in many countries in the region. It can operate directly or through proxies; it can use armed force or cyberattacks. 
2.	The US could well find itself with no alternative but to devote more military resources to the Middle East and to use them in response to what Iran does, a path that could lead to additional Iranian provocations. — The US currently has 60,000 troops in the Middle East and North Africa, according to the Pentagon. —
3.	All this could occur at a time of growing concern about North Korea’s nuclear and missile programs, Russian military threats to Europe, the weakening of arms-control arrangements meant to curb US-Russian nuclear competition, and the arrival of a new era of technological, economic, military and diplomatic competition with China.
COMMENTS: First thought is that there is a lot of time to go before this question resolves, and a lot can happen in the meantime. ~~~ Key paragraph from my analysis - "The key question then is what the next move from the US would be. This makes me estimate a probability close to the base rate (near zero). Analysis
~~~ On my mind are the key players: 1) Trump admin, 2) the complex web of Iranian decision makers, and - something I haven't seen mentioned much - 3) allies or potential allies of the US and Iran.  1) The best way I have found to understand Trump's foreign policy is through a Jacksonian lens. This type of foreign policy entails a focus at home (witness "America-first") that is unconcerned with trying to accomplish big goals abroad such as spread of democracy or long-term peace. It entails harsh action in defense against imminent danger or to accomplish immediate interests (e.g. Trump's strike against the Soleimani). And it entails avoidance of expending effort overseas, in particular an aversion to engagement in wars. It has been a long-standing public goal of the Trump administration to "end endless wars", something his base supports. I wager this goal is a key part of the administration's decision making.  2) Iran has the capability to perform an action that precipitates a "Yes" resolution to this question (e.g. a terrorist attack on the US, see "To Watch" below). But that is far from its self interest. It seems to me the goals of the regime are self-preservation, getting the US out of Iraq and the broader region, earning the sympathies of other governments, and regaining power through e.g. reduction of sanctions or perhaps getting the bomb one day. The historical base rate of Iranian actions against the US suggest as much - witness the long-term use of proxies and soft targets [1].  Part of this is that Iran cannot appear weak in the face of attacks. Thus, it had to retaliate. We now know what that is - a strike on US-inhabited bases outside of Iran (and perhaps the orchestrated downing of a Boeing plane). Crucially, the supreme leader has said this "concludes" the "proportional" measures [2]. Interestingly, Iraqi leadership said they knew of the strikes ahead of time (Correction: I read this in WaPo, not NYT [10]). There is a chance Iran tried to make sure nobody gets killed.  The key question then is what the next move from the US would be. Trump just said in his address to the nation that "Iran is standing down" - his way of saying he is declaring victory, suggesting that the cycle of military retaliations is over, at least for now. 3) Iran doesn't appear to have allies. Notice that Russia and China's responses to the recent news have been extremely muted. This limits how much they can do. ~~~
To watch
~~~ - Further escalation is more likely if Iran:
* Helped organize a terrorist attack on Americans
* Took lethal action against American military
* Fired on US vessels
* Gets so close to getting the bomb that it requires an immediate response (not likely in the short term)
- Further, I would watch how China and Russia respond to the US-Iran tensions. Iran will be emboldened if it finds allies. The key parts of the question are; • "A lethal confrontation is one that results in at least one fatality (total, not each) for the national military forces of either side", and
• "either in Iran or at sea". So for example a US strike in Iran killing someone in the Iranian military would count but if only civilians were killed it would not. (In the event of an air strike like that I could see a situation where the Iranians might claim that only civilians were killed but the US would claim that mainly military personnel were killed, so I'm not sure how that would resolve.) Another way this question could resolve as 'Yes' would be if Iran were to successfully strike a US ship in the Gulf of Oman or the Persian Gulf. There are plenty of reports of the US having Navy ships in that area but does Iran have the military capability to get through their defences? Iran's unmanned drones like the Qods Mohajer, Shahed 129 and Kaman 12 can fly long distances then drop bombs but are slow (under 200mph), in other words they were designed to attack Israel.
Iranian missiles however are a different matter. Iran has the Kowsar anti-ship missile for example which flies at mach 0.8, is precision guided and has a semi-armour piercing warhead. I'd guess the US would have the technology to defend against something like that but;
a) only one has to get through and kill a US sailor for the question to resolve as 'Yes', and
b) even if the attack failed it could trigger the US to retaliate causing military fatalities on Iranian soil. Iran can't win a full out war with the US and they have seen in the past that the US has been prepared to invade countries in the Middle East, so unless they have a suicide wish they won't want to get into an out-and-out war or provoke the US into a land war or invasion. One option for the Iranian leadership is to do nothing. The death of Soleimani seems to have generated a lot of domestic political capital which they could simply bank. I guess they are right now trying to decide what if anything to do in response, and if they do respond, how much restraint will the US show?

Okay, I will no go to a more complete analysis with the help of two braindead outside/inside view combos and then using a really braindead model, which I will use for my final estimation of a 71% probability. First a caveat: the reason of using really simple models for estimating the probability is because it is the best way of doing a post-mortem if your prediction fails. In contrast, if one has used standard subjective judgement and hand-waving of probabilities, the post-mortem will be much more subtle and difficult. Let's begin with two braindead outside/inside view combos: 0.a) Outside view: two options, we continue with proxy conflicts or we escalate to direct conflict. Assign 1/2 probability to each and 50% of a positive resolution for this answer. For the inside view: proxy is still much more convenient than direct. The probability of continuing with proxy is therefore higher than direct, for instance twice as high.  In this case we end up with 2/3 proxy and 1/3 direct and a 33% of a positive resolution. 0.b) Outside view: three options, proxy, direct, deescalation, with 1/3 each and a 33% of a positive resolution. For the inside view, deescalation looks unlikely. We reduce it from 1/3 to 1/10. Proxy still twice as likely as direct. We end up with 60% proxy, 30% direct and 10% deescalation and 30% of a positive resolution. Notice that braindead models 0.a and 0.b support the estimations of a few good forecasters. For a good example:  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/939921 0.c) Outside view: in the last twenty years we have had two large invasions of countries, Afghanistan and Iraq. Then we have a base rate of 10% for a similar thing happening in Iran. Inside view: Iran's geography makes a large-scale military action, that would almost certainly lead to a yes resolution, more unlikely. I will divide this number by half, to 5%. Now with outside view 0.c the previous probabilities in 0.a and 0.b have to be slightly modified, becoming 0.05 + 0.95 * p_previous, with p_previous the old one. We end up with 34-36%. Finally, the braindead model: 1.a) Number of attacks by each side: we are going to do a mixture of imperfect tit-for-tat with gratuitous attacks. Based on my previous post [1], which is based on a very handy timeline by Al-Jazeera [2], there seems to be an unprovoked Iranian attack every three months or so. This gives a total of 4 attacks for 2020. The second thing is that the US does not necessarily do tit-for-tat, but instead seems to be more restrained. I used a 50% probability of retaliation for taking into account the current insider view, but a 30% seems to be more realistic. With the 50% we have two retaliatory actions for the 4 expected random attacks. Third, I assume Iran will retaliate for the killing of Suleimani and will further retaliate back if the US retaliates. This adds 2 Iranian attacks and 1 US attack to the current count We end up with 6 Iranian attacks and 3 American attacks, though the numbers can move a lot. 1.b) Probability of a death at sea or at Iranian soul per attack: for this I assign a probability of hitting a target containing personnel of the other's side military within the frontiers (p) specified in the question followed by the probability of such personnel dying (s). For Iran: p = 10% (they must hit a vessel for that), s = 50%
For the US: p = 50% (well, too high too, but they have the capabilities), s = 50% Now with that I compute the probability of no-one dying, which is the easiest thing to compute. This is given by these simple Mathematica code:  Pnc[n_, p_, s_] := 
 Sum[Binomial[n, r] (1 - p)^(n - r) p^r (1 - s)^r, {r, 0, n}] which refers to the probability of non-causalities. With the 6 Iranian and 3 US attacks, they are: 72 and 42%. Combining them: 31% of no-causalities, 69% of causalities. 1.c) For the final touch, I include 0.c in the equation, ending up with (0.05 + 0.95*0.69) = 0.71, which is my current estimation. 1.d) In the future the model can be improved by considering a probability distribution for the number of Iranian and American attacks, which can be combined with the probabilities obtained in 1.b to get a better estimate. However, I feel that this is overkill for the moment. 1.e) By using this model and playing with the input probabilities we can get a feel of how the factors interplay with each other. With more realistic estimates, for instance 30% of retaliation and maybe a 40% of direct attack to Iran by the US, we will end up with a 45% of yes or even lower. The estimation of these probabilities will be clearer in a few days, I would expect. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/940568

Trump has characterized himself as a stable genius, but is widely perceived as being an unstable idiot. In this case, that perception works to his advantage. I have absolutely no idea how Trump would react to any Iranian retaliation for the Soleimani killing. I don't think anyone else here or elsewhere has any idea either, and that certainly includes the leadership in Tehran. One assumption that I would say is safe to make, however, is that Trump doesn't care about "proportional" responses, and he is completely indifferent to domestic or international criticism, which has been relentless since he entered political life.  If I am correct, the risk presented to the Iranian regime may be unacceptably high. While they can't let the killing of Soleimani go unanswered, they can't take the chance that Trump would be willing to undertake the kind of retaliation that would prompt a popular uprising against the regime. I should add that I doubt if Trump would launch such a strike except as a riposte to an Iranian move, but if Iran retaliates against U.S. naval assets, for example, I think anything can happen. Similarly, if Iran is responsible for the loss of American lives (especially civilian lives), Trump may launch a retaliatory strike with the objective of a destabilizing the Iranian regime. I don't think that there will be a popular rallying in support of the regime in the event of U.S. strikes against the IRGC or the Iranian oil industry, or the regime in general. There tends to reach a point in a protracted struggle that the rank-and-file on one side simply decides that the sacrifices have been too great, and that capitulation is preferable to continued strife. Examples are the Russians in 1917, the Germans in 1918, or the French in 1815 (or perhaps 1940, for that matter). But I think that 40 years of Islamic revolution are probably more than enough for most Iranians, and they would prefer a more stable country and a more uneventful existence. Just a hunch, based on my reading of history. Thus, I think that the chances of a clash at sea, or a strike against Iran are rather narrow, because the clerical regime will be too reluctant to take the chance of provoking Trump.

All responsible parties have been urging the utmost in restraint throughout the day.
With that noted - 
Targeting drones on non-state actors has made drone strikes customary, regular, unspectacular.
It's become a trope in movie thrillers.
That has dulled the assessment of the severity of this action.
This was not the  killing of yet-another non-state actor -but the killing of an active-duty, senior military official serving an existing nation-state. The US has a standing XO against assassinating heads of state - but even that relies ultimately on judgment, not on law.
Judgement being noticeably absent here - this killing brings us to a new game.
With a new game come new rules and new ways of being.. The initial response from Iran likely remains asymmetrical - militias attacking troops in Iraq,  bringing down some part of the grid, or air traffic control -  these and similar are beyond the purview of the question. But ground-based missiles and fast attack torpedoes fired against Gulf shipping (particularly Saudi),or drone attacks against on other Saudi installations - either or both retaliated by the US,, is an easy reflection upon how the scope of the question might get resolved. Further  - without an ability to strike the US directly - preemptive attacks upon Iranian targets becomes tempting, if not habitual.
It could manifest as a strike against Iranian missile sites now re-operative since the October 2019 cyber attack, or a strike against the naval support facilities for the Iranian fast attack craft  - the rationale being the in-advance protection of navigation and allies.
Or an attack upon Iranian nuclear fuel facilities - the rationale being to finish what JCPOA did not.. The question has a one year life - which give time for both the incalculable and the calculable. Thus, it gets a high initial assessment.

It’s certainly possible, but at this point, if it happens, it would likely be the result of local-level miscalculation and blindly following bureaucratic routines and SOPs rather than any deliberate government policy on either side. Iran’s  objective is not to goad the US into a costly conventional war they know they are unlikely to win, but rather lure the US into an unconventional proxy conflict in Iraq or elsewhere in which they do stand a realistic chance of winning or at least obtaining a favorable settlement. Their interests are much better served (and at much lower cost) by standing back while their proxies and clients do all the dirty work of bloodying US forces with the help of Iranian arms and advisors, ultimately drawing the US into a long-term, un-winnable stalemate and war of attrition, and waiting for the US to inevitably defeat itself through growing public divisions and yawning government “credibility gaps” (no doubt supplemented with a healthy dose of Russia-aided social-media psy-ops and propaganda warfare campaign). This is exactly what the Iranian military has been preparing for over the past 10-15 years. Assuring this outcome also gives incentive to higher-ups in the Iranian government to demand that ground-level officers and bureaucrats exercise additional restraint and tighten up their procedures to circumvent the possibility of an untimely direct confrontation between conventional forces at the present stage that could escalate into an undesirable scenario.  In the wake of yesterday’s air strike, the Iranians must certainly have taken note of headlines like this one the New York Times: “U.S. Strike on Iranian General Divides Congress” that indicate little public support at the moment for a war against Iran and unease over Trump’s actions. Thus, they are unlikely to respond with a spectacular show of force—say, sinking an aircraft carrier resulting in thousands of US casualties or shutting off the Straits of Hormuz and causing widespread economic upheaval. Such actions would not only risk fomenting a “rally around the flag” effect in the US, but Iran also knows that these domestic divisions constrain the extent the US government can respond. Keeping the US public divided is all-around in their best interests. Additionally, notice how in the wake of yesterday’s assassination, Khamenei took to Twitter to express revenge, rather than an address to the nation— as would be expected if we were on the precipice of a grave crisis. Twitter messages should be seen as more for external consumption. This fact alone should speak volumes to analysts. Another thing to keep in mind is that wars don’t just materialize out of thin air. They require months of preparation and planning which produce indicators that can’t be hidden from prying eyes. Things like: mobilization orders, reserve call-ups, cancelling leave, intensified military exercises and training, transportation and communication restrictions in key staging areas, shortages and rationing of food and fuel, unusual large-scale orders for things like body bags and medical supplies, intensified internal propaganda and patriotic messaging to prepare the populace, conducting civil defense drills, etc. Thus far, we have seen none of these things in Iran. Nor have we seen any meaningful movement of US assets to the region. Thus far, there is nothing to indicate either side is gearing up for or expecting a major conflict in the near term. What will likely happen is that the Soleimani story will fade from the headlines—just as the Iranian drone shoot-down and Saudi oil facility attack did. Instead, Iran will respond to this quietly by activating and arming their various militia networks, like the Mehdi Army, in Iraq and possibly other places like Syria or Yemen to continue carrying out small-scale attacks on US interests in the Middle East with the objective of enticing the US into Vietnam II. Also, from the US perspective, keeping the Iranian situation at a simmer without boiling over is also very much in the interests of the US and the rest of the Middle East because it has been providing an impetus for a nascent rapprochement between Israel, Saudi Arabia, and the Gulf States, which could ultimately lead to accomplishing an overriding long-term US objective in the region: Arab-Israeli peace. All-out conflict would remove this incentive at this stage, though Iran might also try to draw Israel into any proxy conflict with the hope of dividing this burgeoning Israel-Sunni anti-Iran alliance by inflaming the “Arab Street.”
